content: The Act may be cited as the "Domestic Partnership Benefits and Obligations Act of 2007" and provides benefits to domestic partners of federal employees. The "Domestic Partnership Benefits and Obligations Act of 2007" grants benefits to federal employees with domestic partners, who must file an affidavit certifying their relationship to receive benefits and assume obligations similar to those of married couples. The "Domestic Partnership Benefits and Obligations Act of 2007" requires domestic partners of federal employees to share financial responsibilities, be exclusive, be of the same sex, and not related in a way that would prohibit legal marriage if they were of opposite sexes. Willful falsification of information may result in disciplinary action. Employees must report the dissolution of their partnership within 30 days to the Office of Personnel Management. Benefits received by a domestic partner under the Act will terminate if the partnership dissolves by any means other than the death of the employee or partner. The former domestic partner of an employee is entitled to benefits and obligations similar to a former spouse if the partnership dissolves by any means other than death. Any child of a domestic partner is considered a stepchild of the employee for benefit purposes. Information submitted to the Office of Personnel Management is confidential and used only for certifying eligibility. The Office of Personnel Management must establish regulations within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Office of Personnel Management must establish regulations within 6 months of the Act's enactment for implementing benefits and obligations in the executive branch and other entities. Each agency or entity outside the executive branch administering programs must also promulgate regulations to implement the Act within the same timeframe. The Act requires regulations for implementing benefits and obligations in the executive branch and other entities, including health insurance, dental and vision benefits, retirement, and disability benefits. Regulations must be promulgated after notice and comment. A domestic partner is defined as an unmarried adult living with another unmarried adult. The term "employee" refers to an officer or employee of the United States, excluding members of the uniformed services.
